titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Captain Wells broke off from his agreement for our passage, to my great disappointment— We dined with Mr: Pitcairn— Mr: Ellis an English Gentleman dined there— Rainy evening.
2. A Heavy thunder shower this morning; and rainy weather at intervals all day. Mrs: Pitcairn spent the evening with Mrs: A— and I with him at chess— Wrote to Mr: Murray.
3. Walk about the town and round upon the ramparts before breakfast— Went for a couple of hours before dinner to hunt up lodgings. Spent the evening with Mr: Pitcairn.

4. Agreed again to go with Captain Wills— I was obliged by necessity to pay him his encreased demand. It is not the first instance in which I have seen the expediency of submitting with a good grace to imposition. Call’d on Mr: Pitcairn before dinner: found Mr: Skinner with him— Dined with Mr: Parish at his country-seat— About half the Senate of Hamburg there— The company two or three and twenty— Spent the Evening with Pitcairn.

5. We dined with Mr: Pitcairn, and after dinner took a ride into the Country, along the banks of the Alster & to a public house and gardens just beyond Altona, where we found a very numerous company— Evening with Pitcairn— We had bad weather for our ride.

6. Writing letters in the forenoon. We went with Mrs: Pitcairn in the evening to the french play; where we saw Didon; a great Opera— The words and music are both excellent— The latter by Piccini— Mlle: Gavaudan who play’d the part of Dido is a pretty good actress, and an indifferent singer.— Called at the bookseller Perthes’s. Settled my accounts with Pitcairn.

7. Making all our final preparations to embark. Left with Perthes a list of the books I wish to have sent me. We dined and spent the Evening with Mr: Pitcairn, of whom we took leave— We have been much indebted to him for every species of kindness and attention during our stay here.

8. Mr: Medford of London called on me this forenoon and gave me a letter for America— He came from England last week— Mrs: Pitcairn came and took leave of Mrs: A— At about 4 o’clock this afternoon we went with Captain Wills on board a lighter in the river, and came down to the ship, which we reached between 7 and 8 in the evening.

9. The wind has been against us the whole day, and blew very strong; the ship however work’d down with the tide several miles— The prevalence of westerly winds at this season makes it difficult to get down this river.

10. It blew a storm almost the whole day— We came however somewhat further down the river. The motion of the ship, was so great as to make several of us sick— I am reading La Harpe’s Cours de Littérature.

11. I enter upon my thirty-fifth year, with a grateful heart to a kind Providence for its great indulgence through the course of my life hitherto, and with a supplication for the means of making my future days, days of usefulness— We had stormy weather again; but towards night came down within a few miles of Cuxhaven & the mouth of the river.

12. At about 3 o’clock this morning the wind proving fair we got under weigh, and without stopping at-all at Cuxhaven came at once out to sea; the pilot left us at about 6— Before 8 we had a sight of the island of Heiligeland and before noon were out of sight of all land— The weather through the day was thick and rainy— Most of us were sick— I was not thoroughly so— As we came out we spoke the ship Indus from Boston.

13. In the night and all this forenoon it blew almost a gale of wind— I continued unwell all day, though not entirely sick— Mrs: A— and the child hitherto support the voyage better than I could have hoped— Towards night the weather became fair, and the wind died away to a calm. We have seen several vessels at a distance in the course of the day— Spoke none of them.

14. We had a total calm all last night and the greatest part of this day— Towards evening a little breeze sprung up. We saw several vessels and lay all day in sight of the Texel island— The weather fair and pleasant— I wrote, part of the forenoon.

15. A fresh wind brought us over in the night almost to the English coast— But at ten this morning, the Captain found it so questionable for going into the channel that he finally determined to go North about and took the course accordingly— One of the reasons for preferring this way is that there is some danger in passing into the channel without a pilot.— We had a fresh and favourable wind all day, and saw a great number of vessels— Among the rest an English frigate. Who shewed us her colours; but upon our shewing ours pass’d on—

16. All last night and this day we had a very fresh breeze which carried us from seven to nine knots an hour in thirty hours time we have run not less than four degrees northward— The difference in the length of the day is greater than I ever witnessed. Last night it was dark by nine o’clock in the evening— This night it was still light at midnight.

17. Spoke this morning to a dutch fishing boat. Told us we were fourteen leagues distant from Fair island, bearing N.N.W.— But the weather which began to be very foggy yesterday continued so all this day, untill it became so thick that nothing was to be seen at the distance of 1/4 of a mile— In this situation at about 7 in the evening, the land was spied just under the ship’s bow; She was in no small danger of stranding, and had just time to put about and steer back the way she came— Mrs: A— much alarm’d and afterwards quite ill.

18. The fogs continued in immediate succession all night and the whole of this day— The ship could do nothing but steer alternately to and fro— These vapours are too powerful even for the Sun, for above them the sky was perfectly clear— We caught several dog-fish & others this afternoon— Captain very irritable.

19. The weather became a little clearer this morning and we made the land, of the Orkney islands. At about noon, a small boat row’d up to the ship while about three leagues distant from the shore. There were five men in the boat; one of them a young man who by the Captain’s invitation dined with us. He said his name was Streng, and that his father was the proprietor of the most part of Sanda Island, from which he had come to the ship— The boat belonged to fair island which lies about half ways between the Orkney, and Shetland isles, and distant about 25 miles from each.— Two men had come in it to get some grain which in fair island was very scarce— They brought on board a couple of lambs, some chickens and some fish, both salt and fresh, for which they would take no money, but asked for rum, tobacco, fishing-lines, soap, old-cloathes, and in short any thing we chose to give them— Mr: Streng told us that Sanda was acknowledg’d to be the prettiest of all the Orkney islands; and told us how happy his father would be to see us on shore— He left us at about two o’clock and promis’d to send us a pilot from the shore as soon as possible— But very soon after he went away a thick fog came up, and we were obliged to stand away from the land.

20. Fine clear weather this morning, and we pass’d between Fair island and the Orkney isles, from the North Sea into the Atlantic Ocean; the weather soon thickened up again, and we could only keep a North-west course— Saw a couple of vessels in the forenoon.

21. The wind still adverse all the morning with thick fog, and calm all the afternoon, and evening— At night the weather cleared and a breeze sprung up; but soon came directly a head— Saw several vessels and a great number of fish. B.
22. The fogs have at length disappeared, and in their stead we have brisk head-winds, which oblige us to keep a northerly course— Weather extremely cold and disagreeable— Saw one vessel this day.

23. Still beating to and fro with the winds a-head; this day the weather though very cold was not quite so unpleasant as yesterday— We do little more than run alternately north-ward and Southward— Saw nothing.

24. Fresh winds which allow us no other than a north-westerly course; which we ran the whole of this day. The weather becomes more and more cold— The captain expected this evening to make the Ferroe islands— At midnight we have broad day— We see nothing here but whales and a great variety of sea-birds.

25. At length this morning at four o’clock, in the latitude of 62 North, the winds allowed us, to steer a southward course without driving us easterly. We ran so the whole day; and in the evening, we were able to get a little westward— Still saw great numbers of whales and of birds; but nothing human.

26. For the first time since we pass’d into the Atlantic we have kept our true course— In the last ten days we have not advanced so much as a good run for twenty-four hours would give us. We now go South-west, and begin to find a milder climate.
27. A fair and fresh breeze which grew stronger as the day pass’d and in the evening carried us ten knots an hour. We saw nothing.
28. Wind abated in the night, and this morning left us a thick fog and a calm. We saw a vessel at a distance, the first for several days. Towards night we had just wind enough to clear off the fog.
29. A light and favourable breeze this morning, which kept freshening the whole day and in the evening carried the ship, ten knots an hour.
30. The wind continued to blow all night and through the whole of this day almost a gale— In the last twenty-four hours we ran 217 miles. We have long nights again— Lat: 51:57. Long: 21:50.
31. Still a very fresh and fair breeze; which however abated in the course of the morning and dwindled almost to a calm. From noon to noon 208 miles. Lat: 49:57. Long: 26.

Day. The life on board ship is so uniform that the only difference between one day and another, is that of the wind. I find upon this passage what I have observed upon others heretofore— The sea affects my head—disqualifies me for all application of mind—insomuch that all the time I pass upon the sea is in a manner lost time— I cannot write— And though I read the more, I retain nothing of my reading— Retirement and silence indeed are necessary to reflection and on board ship they are impracticable— On this passage I rise at about 7 in the morning—breakfast at eight—dine at one afternoon—take tea at 6. and turn in between 11 and 12 at night— The intervals are all pass’d alike— When the weather is fair, upon deck, gazing at the skies and the waves; and occasionally looking through the spy-glass at some other vessel we chance to see.— The rest of the time I read— But merely to pass the time; and with a rapidity proportioned to the weakness of attention. I am just finishing the Lycée or Cours de Littérature of Le Harpe, as far as it is yet published, that is the 14th: volume— I suppose there must be at least seven more volumes to come— And the whole will not be worth Blairs Lectures— The book is however amusing— He has indeed nothing original— For his theory he analyses Aristotle—Longinus, Cicero, Horace, Quintilian & Boileau, as for the application he still analyses the great writers of antient & modern french literature. This method might perhaps be prescribed by the character of the authors auditory at the Lyceum, and has its use for the reader; but it injures the work as an elementary treatise.
